resources.string: Allows an application to access AdServices Topics API.
Allows an application to access AdServices Attribution APIs.
Allows an application to access AdServices Custom Audience API.
Allows an application to access AdId API.
Allows an application to access AdServices Consent API.
Allows an application to access Ad ID API.
Access to App Set ID API
Allows an application to access App Set ID API.
Allows an application to access Consent Service API.
Test the new Privacy Sandbox system that restricts cross-app tracking
Data is collected in the Privacy Sandbox to show you ads you might like, but is shared without identifying you or your device.
What kind of data is stored in the Privacy Sandbox?

Android generates this data based on the apps you use, and adds it to the Privacy Sandbox. For example, one of your general interests might be “Sports.” \n\nYou can see the list of your interests in your Privacy settings, and block any you don’t like.

Your apps generate this data based on how you use them, and add it to the Privacy Sandbox. For example, an app you use to shop for running shoes might add the label sport_running.\n\nIn your privacy settings, you can see the list of apps doing this, and block any app from contributing data to the Privacy Sandbox.

Android’s Privacy Sandbox restricts cross-app tracking while still allowing apps to show you ads you might like. Android shares this data with advertisers without identifying you or your device.\n\nBased on the apps you use, Android generates and updates this list of your general ads interests. If you block an interest, it won’t be added to the list again unless you unblock it. You may still see some related ads.

Android generates these interests based on the apps you use.

For example, if you have several sports apps on your device, Android might add the interest “Sports” to the Privacy Sandbox.

Later, this data is shared with advertisers without identifying you or your device.
Your apps that generate specific interests
Manage your apps that generate specific interests

Based on how you use them, some apps generate data about your specific ads interests for the Privacy Sandbox. Android updates this list of apps so you can view or edit it.\n\nIf you block an app, it won’t add any more specific interests. It won’t be added to this list again unless you unblock it. Interests already generated by the app will be deleted, but you may still see some related ads.
No apps to show right now

Some apps you use generate data about your specific interests for advertising, and add it to the Privacy Sandbox.

For example, an app you use to shop for running shoes might add the label sport_running.

Later, data collected in the Privacy Sandbox is shared with advertisers without identifying you or your device. So you still see ads you might like, but with greater privacy protection.
No blocked apps to show right now
No interests to show right now
Manage your general interests for ads
No blocked interests to show right now
Test new features that will restrict cross-app tracking
You’re now part of the Privacy Sandbox beta. \n\nYou can learn more or leave the beta any time, in your Privacy settings.
Thanks for your response. You haven’t been added to the Privacy Sandbox beta.\n\nIf you change your mind or want to learn more, go to your privacy settings.
You’re testing new features that restrict cross-app tracking
You’re helping Android restrict cross-app tracking
Android is testing new features that will restrict cross-app tracking by advertisers
Today, data about your app usage can easily be associated with your device, then shared across apps for advertising purposes.

Android is testing a new Privacy Sandbox that securely stores and shares advertising data — without identifying you or your device. \n\nThis new system helps prevent apps from passing data directly to other apps, but still allows them to show you ads you might like.
While you may not notice changes in the ads you see, being part of the beta will help Android restrict cross-app tracking over time. You can leave the beta any time by going to your privacy settings.
Data is collected in the Privacy Sandbox to show you ads you might like, but is shared without identifying you or your device.
What kind of data will be stored in the Privacy Sandbox?

Android generates this data based on the apps you use, and adds it to the Privacy Sandbox. For example, one of your general interests might be "Sports."\n\nYou can see the list of your interests in your Privacy settings, and block any you don’t like.

Your apps generate this data based on how you use them, and add it to the Privacy Sandbox. For example, an app you use to shop for running shoes might add the label sport_running.\n\nIn your privacy settings, you can see the list of apps doing this, and block any app from contributing data to the sandbox.
